case_name: Indian Oxygen Acetylene Co. Private Ltd. v. Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 753 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 753 of 1957. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 6th October, 1956, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  Nos. 40 44 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and Order dated 6th October 1956 of Industrial Tribunal Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 6th October, 1956, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  Nos. 40 44 of 1956. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, N. A. Palkhivala, J. B. Dadachanji and S. N. Andley, for the appellant.

facts.text: Reference I.T. Nos. 40 and 44 of 1956 before Industrial Tribunal Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  Nos. 40 44 of 1956.

facts.text: Bonus dispute between Indian Oxygen Acetylene Co. Private Ltd. (appellant) and its workmen (respondents) for years 1952-53 and 1953-54

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises from a bonus dispute between the Indian Oxygen Acetylene Co., Private Ltd.,  hereafter called the appellant  and its workmen, the relevant years for the bonus claim being 1952- 53 and 1953-54.

facts.text: Claim made separately by workmen excluding clerical staff (Ref. I.T. No. 40 of 1956) and by clerical staff (Ref. I.T. No. 44 of 1956)

anchor.surface_text: This claim was made separately by the workmen excluding the members of the clerical staff as well as by the clerical staff and the two claims thus made were referred by the Bombay Government to the Industrial Tribu- nal for its adjudication. The claim raised by the workmen excluding clerical staff was numbered as Ref.  I. T.  No. 40 of 1956, while that made by the clerical staff was numbered as Ref.  1. T.  No. 44 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant is private limited company incorporated in 1935 with head office at Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: Both categories of workmen will hereafter be described as the respondents in this judgment. The appellant is a private limited companypany incorporated in 1935 and it has its head office at Calcutta.

facts.text: Appellant manufactures and sells oxygen and acetylene

anchor.surface_text: Its business is to manufacture and sell oxygen and acetylene. It is a subsidiary of the British Oxygen Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Appellant is subsidiary of British Oxygen Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It is a subsidiary of the British Oxygen Co. Ltd. It sells its products to the hospitals and nursing homes and in large quantities to industrial companycerns for welding, cutting and blasting operations.

facts.text: Appellant voluntarily paid bonus equal to two months basic wages for 1952-53 and 1953-54

anchor.surface_text: It voluntarily paid bonus equal to two months basic wages for both the years in dispute but the respondents were number satisfied with the said payment and they made a claim for 1/3 of their total earnings for the two respective years.

facts.text: Respondents claimed bonus of 1/3 of their total earnings for 1952-53 and 1953-54

anchor.surface_text: but the respondents were number satisfied with the said payment and they made a claim for 1/3 of their total earnings for the two respective years. That is bow the dispute arose between the parties.

facts.text: All shares of appellant excepting two or three held by nominee shareholders are held by British Oxygen Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It appears in evidence that all the shares of the appellant  excepting two or three held by numberinee shareholders  are held by the British Oxygen Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Appellant has been prospering and expanding at rapid rate

anchor.surface_text: Evidence also shows that the appellant has been prospering and has been expanding at a rapid rate.

facts.text: Appellant capitalised reserves in 1940, 1941, 1942, 1945, 1946, 1947, 1949

anchor.surface_text: In has capitalised its reserves in 1940, 1941, 1942, 1945, 1946, 1947 and 1949 with the result that the major portion of its capital is made up of bonus shares.

facts.text: Appellant made good profits for year ending September 30, 1953 and September 30, 1954

anchor.surface_text: It has made good profits for the year ending September 30, 1953, as well as for the year ending September 30, 1954.

facts.text: Large gap exists between actual wages paid by appellant to workmen and living wage

anchor.surface_text: There is also numberdoubt that a large gap exists between the actual wages paid by it to its workmen and the living wage.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded it was paying good wages and respondents not entitled to additional bonus under formula

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded that it was paying good wages to the respondents and that under the formula the respondents were number entitled to claim any additional bonus for the relevant years.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected appellant's case and directed payment of bonus at 1/4 annual basic wages for 1952-53 and 1/3 for 1953-54 less already paid

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has, however, rejected the appellants case and has directed it to pay to the respondents bonus at the rate of 1/4 of the annual basic wages for 1952-53 and 1/3 of the said wages for 1953-54  less the bonus already paid for these years .

facts.text: Tribunal directed exclusion of overtime, dearness and other allowances in calculating bonus amount

anchor.surface_text: It has also directed that in calculating the amount of bonus overtime and dearness and other allowances should be excluded.

facts.text: Tribunal calculated available surplus without rehabilitation as Rs. 6,14,830 for 1952-53 and Rs. 12,16,120 for 1953-54

anchor.surface_text: According to the calculations made by the Tribunal, without providing for any rehabilitation  Ex. TA  it has reached the companyclusion that the available surplus for the years 1952-53 and 1953-54 respectively would be Rs. 6,14,830/- and Rs. 12,16,120/-.

facts.text: Tribunal alternatively found no available surplus if rehabilitation claim allowed

anchor.surface_text: However, the Tribunal has found  1  1959 S.C.R. 925. 1006 alternatively that in case the claim for rehabilitation made by the appellant has to be awarded, then there would be numberavailable surplus for both the relevant years.

facts.text: Hearing date: May 5, 1959

anchor.surface_text: Janardhan Sharma and B. P. Maheshwari, for the Intervener. 1959. May 5.

facts.text: Appellant brought into account one-half of general reserve as on Sep 30 1953 (Rs. 5,51,363) and Sep 30 1954 (Rs. 3,95,376)

anchor.surface_text: But apart from this aspect of the matter, it is clear that the appellant has brought into account one-half of its general reserve as on September 30,1953, and September 30, 1954, respectively, and these amounts are Rs. 5,51,363 and Rs. 3,95,376.

facts.text: Previous awards allowed 20% of net profits to appellant for rehabilitation and expansion

anchor.surface_text: In the previous awards to which our attention was drawn by the respondents, 20 of the net profits appear to have been awarded to the appellant on a rough and ready basis, by way of provision for rehabilitation as well as expansion.

facts.text: Tribunal impressed by evidence of Mr. Saigal and Mr. Basak on rehabilitation

anchor.surface_text: The award shows that the tribunal was very favorably impressed by the evidence given by Mr. Saigal and Mr. Basak on behalf of the appellant.

Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 6th October, 1956, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  Nos. 40 44 of 1956. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, N. A. Palkhivala, J. B. Dadachanji and S. N. Andley, for the appellant.

The first point which the appellant has urged is against the finding of the tribunal that it was number bound to give effect to the Full Bench formula. In determining the available surplus the Tribunal has taken the view that the formula was number binding on it and that on companysiderations of social justice to which it has referred it was open to it to reject the claim of the appellant for rehabilitation.

issues.text: Whether the Industrial Tribunal was bound to give effect to the Full Bench formula in determining the available surplus or could it reject the appellant's claim for rehabilitation on considerations of social justice?

anchor.surface_text: The first point which the appellant has urged is against the finding of the tribunal that it was number bound to give effect to the Full Bench formula. In determining the available surplus the Tribunal has taken the view that the formula was number binding on it and that on companysiderations of social justice to which it has referred it was open to it to reject the claim of the appellant for rehabilitation.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal was wrong in taking into account the price level prevailing in 1956 for rehabilitation calculations instead of confining to the price level in the bonus years?

anchor.surface_text: However, the Tribunal has found  1  1959 S.C.R. 925. 1006 alternatively that in case the claim for rehabilitation made by the appellant has to be awarded, then there would be numberavailable surplus for both the relevant years. ... The first point which has been urged by the respondents in this behalf is that the Tribunal was wrong in taking into account the price level prevailing in 1956.

issues.text: Whether in making rehabilitation calculations the tribunal had to take into account substantial amounts previously allowed to the appellant by way of rehabilitation in previous awards?

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that in making its calculations the tribunal has number applied its mind to the fact that, though the appellant has been allowed substantial amounts by way of rehabilitation in previous awards, those amounts are number brought into account in companysidering its claims for rehabilitation. ... So we would accept the respondents companytention that the appellant is bound to take into companysideration the amount previously allowed to it by way of rehabilitation.

issues.text: Whether the tribunal erred in accepting the appellant's claim and calculations for rehabilitation, including the use of weighted average method by Mr. Basak?

anchor.surface_text: The award shows that the tribunal was very favorably impressed by the evidence given by Mr. Saigal and Mr. Basak on behalf of the appellant. It appears that in arriving at the average life of the buildings, machinery, etc., Mr. Basak has adopted the method of weighted average. This method is a development of the companycept of the 1008 ordinary arithmetic mean

holdings.text: The Tribunal was in error in not granting to the appellant its claim for rehabilitation as industrial tribunals must give effect to the Full Bench formula.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the said decision we must hold that the Tribunal was in error in not granting to the appellant its claim for rehabilitation. According to the calculations made by the Tribunal, without providing for any rehabilitation Ex. TA it has reached the conclusion that the available surplus

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in C.C. Ltd., Bombay v. Their Workmen requiring tribunals to apply Full Bench formula in bonus claims.

holdings.text: The Tribunal did not err in taking into account the price level prevailing in 1956 for rehabilitation calculations.

anchor.surface_text: We have considered this point in A.C.C.s case 1 and we have held that it is inexpedient to confine the relevant decision of the Tribunal solely to the price level prevailing in the bonus years. Therefore the objection that the Tribunal has committed an error

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in A.C.C. case holding it inexpedient to limit to bonus years' price levels.

holdings.text: The appellant is bound to take into consideration the amount previously allowed to it by way of rehabilitation unless shown to have been spent.

anchor.surface_text: In the A.C.C.s case 1 we have held that if an amount for rehabilitation is allowed to an employer and it appears that during the relevant year the said amount was available to him then in subsequent years the said amount will have to be taken into account unless it is shown that

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies rule from A.C.C. case; notes appellant accounted for half general reserve and prior awards mixed rehabilitation with expansion.

holdings.text: The Tribunal did not err in accepting the appellant's rehabilitation calculations using weighted average method; respondents failed to show errors.

anchor.surface_text: The award shows that the tribunal was very favorably impressed by the evidence given by Mr. Saigal and Mr. Basak on behalf of the appellant. It appears that in arriving at the average life of the buildings, machinery, etc., Mr. Basak has adopted the method of weighted average.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence satisfactory; weighted average scientifically accurate; no material infirmities in cross-examination or calculations.

holdings.text: On the alternative finding of no available surplus if rehabilitation allowed, the appellant succeeds and the award is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Thus it would be clear that on the alternative finding made by the Tribunal the appellant would be entitled to succeed and the award under appeal would have to be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's alternative calculations upheld after rejecting challenges; no surplus means no additional bonus.

holdings.text: The employer is not entitled to claim a prior charge under the formula for any item of expansion.

anchor.surface_text: It is not well settled that the employer is not entitled to claim a prior charge under the formula for any item of expansion but the awards previously passed between the appellant and its workmen seem to have allowed for a claim for expansion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled doctrine under Full Bench formula.

holdings.text: The weighted average method is scientifically more accurate for determining average life of assets in rehabilitation claims.

anchor.surface_text: This method is a development of the concept of the ordinary arithmetic mean. Under this method, in general terms, a set of quantities X is given, to each of which is attached a weight W, and the weighted arithmetic mean is obtained

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gives realistic result; illustrated by tribunal example showing superiority over arithmetic mean.

holdings.text: Exhausted assets should be continued in weighted average calculations as they give correct picture of assets in use.

anchor.surface_text: We are inclined to think that the method adopted by the appellant in making its calculations gives a more correct picture of the assets actually in use and the rehabilitation cost claimed in respect of them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Asset in existence and use justifies rehabilitation claim.

holdings.text: Including both ending old assets and new assets in same year does not create double rehabilitation claim.

anchor.surface_text: We are not satisfied that even this argument is wellfounded. Let us examine this argument by reference to one item. The lease-hold buildings of the appellant include two buildings known as D.A. and Oxygen respectively at Bombay Ex. C. 19.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Example of leasehold buildings shows no inflation; normal depreciation deducted.
